articles.title: The Telekinetic Phenomena of Lamia 1929
articles.excerpt: Report on the telekinetic phenomena and psychic investigation in Lamia, led by Angelos Tanagras.

content.value: Much was said recently about the telekinetic phenomena in Lamia, where about a year ago stones began falling on hotelier Stoukas' house, causing panic. To get a reliable opinion we turned to Angelos Tanagras, the only Greek specialist in Psychic Research, who told us the following:

Well, said Mr. Tanagras, some people, when they hear something beyond what they know, shrug and smile as if they have solved all the problems of the universe. One of them forty years ago laughed at the phonograph, calling believers fools. Yet they themselves accept far more astonishing things: that Earth is a round sphere with fiery liquid inside its crust (as volcanoes prove), that right now we are hurtling at 370 km per second toward Capricornus, and much more.

But when they hear of telepathy or telekinesis they look at you with a silly pitying grin. They are like flocks following the shepherd; once the servant and the greengrocer are convinced, they will follow too without realizing it. Most people are like that-fortunately not everyone.
The Lamia phenomena
We asked him to describe the Lamia events. (On his desk among photos and ornaments sat a small ash-colored stone inscribed 'Telekinetic Phenomena of Lamia,' which we asked about.)

Ah yes! he said. It is one of the stones that fell for about a year on Stoukas' house in Lamia. Although such a phenomenon-easy to fake and defraud-is normally disregarded in research, I could not resist taking one for the Psychic Research Museum.

These stones, despite their sometimes considerable weight, caused no harm even when they struck people. A policeman was hit in the stomach and barely felt it. Another, about 1.5 kg, rested on the vines, and a third did not even crack the entry tile when it fell-as if the stones lost their weight. The same effect was recently noted in Czechoslovakia by neurologist Simsa and teacher Vratnik, who studied it in detail with medium Hilda.
Stone-throwing by invisible hands
How long did it last?

A full year with small breaks. The entire Lamia police mobilized to see if it was a malicious attack but found nothing. Imagine the indignation of good Stoukas when neighbors deemed him damned and his home demonic. He decided to leave for his village Kastania.
In vain-the stone-throwing followed him there and returned with him to Lamia in October. Then the phenomena abruptly changed form: the stones stopped and objects began to move.
Machines that walk
First a sewing machine began strolling through the rooms. Then its wooden case did the same.
How is that explained?
Just as a magnet draws iron. It is a simple natural phenomenon.
Where does it come from?
From the same cause as the stone-throwing: someone in the family. As we later confirmed, it was the 13-year-old maid Maria Hani.
Could the girl have produced the phenomena on purpose?
We suspected that at first, but soon realized the stones fell even when Maria was in her room, and the object movements occurred when she was away from the house.
What impression did the movements make?
The family panicked and resorted to religion. The Metropolitan, knowing it was a natural phenomenon, stayed out of it. But Father Spyros Styraatoulos, boasting power over Satan, performed a blessing.
The result: icons, oil lamps, and censers shot from the shrine; Father Spyros fled to a cafe for water to recover his nerves.
Since then objects have not stopped flying. The story spread and crowds came to watch.
Did many witness it?
Who verified it

Crowds of Lamia residents: doctor Mousatos, whose armchair with wooden arms broke before him; Lt. Colonel Kolias; Major Bountouris; Major Gardikis-all observed the phenomena, with sworn statements in the January issue of Psychikai Ereynai.

The funniest was seminary student Chasiakos, who thought it was a hoax. He sat on a chair by the door; suddenly a liter bottle of olive oil 'paid him a visit,' smashing on his seat, drenching him and nicking his neck. He gathered his cassock and ran shouting it was Satan's work.

Then the lit brazier overturned, chairs fell, life in the house became unbearable-even though the hosts, seeing no real damage done, quickly regained courage in their Roumeliote way. Often when an object moved they set it back like a naughty child saying, 'You'll stay there now!'-only for it to fly off again.
The strangest event was moving a 10-month-old baby, the child of tenant Spiridoula Ketiaki. The swaddled infant was shifted three meters from its cradle while sleeping. The mother rushed to grab it.

As neighbors discussed it, a chair fell; before they recovered, a roughly 40-kg table with metal legs began moving on its own. Everyone bolted outside in terror while Spiridoula, holding the baby, begged her husband to leave the house.
How the phenomena are explained
What is their significance?

Immense from a human viewpoint. These phenomena are not aimless like a magnet pulling iron; they prove a conscious force carries them out. That conscious force is emitted from a human body. What shall we call it? Humans always called it 'soul.' Telekinesis is living proof of the soul's existence-a long-sought proof that will persuade the world and give humanity a new mentality.
Have you seen telekinesis yourself?
Yes, in Heraklion, Crete, together with the most skeptical scientists there-doctors Vogiatzakis and Markatatos-whom I invited, fearing hallucination.

Telekinesis exists; it is a fact, as is the existence of soul. That few have seen or believed it means nothing: a phenomenon proven experimentally never disappears. Tomorrow will vindicate those who introduced scientific research on psychic matters to Greece, even if they seek no triumphs.
Empros newspaper - 11 January 1929
Following the previous GSPR communique about 13-year-old medium Maria Hani: the object movements stopped and the medium began having hallucinations.
She thought she saw in the yard a short robed figure-imagined as a saint-ordering her to tell the Stoukas family to leave the house by St. Andrew's eve or suffer great harm.
Terrified, the family followed the GSPR's advice and sent the girl back to her village.
Since then nothing happened-neither on the date she named nor afterwards.
The GSPR will monitor the young medium's development and, if needed, bring her to its offices.

articles.title: An Entire Army of Vampires - Appearing Every Year in Crete
articles.excerpt: Eyewitness accounts of the ghost army at Frangokastello-'vrykolakes' riding at dawn-and Angelos Tanagras' planned investigation after the British SPR failed to capture it.

content.value: Eyewitness tales: all the vrykolakes gallop with their horses, circle the castle, and vanish. Maria Pliakaki recounts with tragic flair; the abbot of Agios Charalambos fears them. British SPR failed-Tanagras seeks a tangible explanation.
The setting

Before Tanagras' interview, we sketch the landscape where the vision of General Chatzimichalis' slaughtered army appears. The Venetian 'Frangokastello' stands on a slope of a massive hill. Jagged rocks rise in front; northeast stand dense cypresses. The phenomenon, per Tanagras' supplementary notes, appears just before sunrise in a light breeze.
Some testimonies
Abbot Charalambis (Hatzipateras) of nearby Agios Charalambos monastery tells Tanagras' team:
'For years each May I see this in the sky. God help us. My grandfather said these are the souls of those slaughtered by the Turks seeking rest.'

When asked what he sees: 'Just before sunrise a haze covers the sky; the sun, half risen, is blood-red. Clouds leap over Frangokastello and-right before our eyes-the vrykolakes of Chatzimichalis! In front the general, behind captain Deliyannakis. They all gallop around the castle and disappear. I see noses, feet, hands, rifles-clearly. When villagers cross themselves, they vanish. They circle Frangokastello 13 times, then the north wind carries them back to the sea.'

Women's accounts are more tragic. Maria Pliakaki: 'Ten years I've seen 'the Greeks.' At dawn at the village well, an old woman screamed: 'Here are the vrykolakes!' We saw black figures in red clouds, frenzied, brandishing swords toward us. Three girls fainted. We burned incense at our windows and they returned to their graves.'

A younger woman objects: 'What graves? They have none-that's why they appear each year. I heard their voices and those of the nun gathering bones. Even the Devil fled because the holy Nun chases him away from their resting place.'
The scientific ambush

Tanagras received reports and letters about the Sfakia phenomenon. Lacking funds, the GSPR couldn't go sooner; society neglects this work. Last year the British SPR sent Bennett and White; the world press covered it; spiritualists claimed reincarnated souls. Everyone has opinions, but the simple folk must be checked against reality.

To verify, Tanagras decided the GSPR would go. It was shameful that foreigners probed a Greek phenomenon. The British team found nothing-the weather was bad and the vision did not appear; they waited days and left. Right after they departed, the 'Greeks' appeared.

The phenomenon reportedly appears late May (new calendar), 15-17 May (old calendar), coinciding with the massacre of Chatzimichalis' force. Tanagras traveled with the hero's great-grandson to the site. Armed with four cameras (loaned by Mrs. Choremi), they set them up: only photographing the vision would solve it. It seemed mass suggestion-but the cause, as all Crete says it sees yearly, was different.
Tanagras' verdict: the phenomenon definitely occurs.

articles.title: 'Haunted Houses' - GSPR Investigations of Their Phenomena
articles.excerpt: Angelos Tanagras' lecture on haunted houses in Mavrovo and Kozani: detailed accounts of telekinetic outbreaks, the medium Kalliopi, and the call for a research institute.

content.value: Astonishing things confirmed in Macedonia
As announced, yesterday afternoon at the Academy hall, Angelos Tanagras delivered his lecture on 'haunted houses' in Mavrovo and Kozani.
The hall was packed with scientists and people from every social class-many ladies present-and the Metropolitans of Corfu and Arta attended.

Tanagras explained how he traveled to Mavrovo and Kozani to study the reported hauntings. The mission was delicate and difficult; it seemed to be telekinesis. He was skeptical, mindful of similar cases described by Lombroso, Flammarion, etc.
What 'haunted houses' mean in science

Haunted houses have been reported worldwide through the ages. In antiquity, Pausanias, accused of treason, took refuge in Athena Chalkioikos' temple. From then on the temple was abandoned because every evening cries and ominous noises were heard.

Pliny described such events and advised Athenians to avoid haunted houses. Skeptical philosopher Athenodoros ignored the warning, moved in, but quickly changed his mind when he heard knocks and saw the ghost of an old man gesture him to the garden, where it vanished. Authorities dug and found a shackled skeleton.
Countless similar tales exist in history and folklore. In earlier times they were blamed on demons; ignorance and superstition branded witnesses as possessed.

Modern science has shed light and offers explanations; observations continue. Suitable mediums are rare-Eusapia Palladino was one years ago-but the case of Kalliopi from Kozani was unprecedented. Trained, she would have far surpassed Palladino, had knowledge been available then.

Tanagras then described his trip to Kastoria, where knowledgeable scientists were systematically following such matters. He met the investigative committee-local scientists and officials-at the village Mavrovo, in the house of former chieftain Mr. Mavromatis, where telekinetic phenomena were reported.
Specters appeared, stones fell, the house was 'possessed.' Fraud was excluded: the host would not allow tricks, and the phenomena themselves disproved deceit.

The Mavromatis family-husband, wife, children, and a young maid-suffered damage to household items. Neighbors could not have caused it; the house was isolated with full visibility around. Imitation was impossible. An eyewitness, villager Papanikolas, while reading a blessing in the house, saw a warm stone fall in the hallway-impossible to throw from outside. The stone was warm from sun; stones fell from 8 p.m. until sunset, all warm.
The first phenomena

Remembering similar descriptions by Lombroso, Flammarion, etc.-knocks on glasses, wood, iron; moving furniture; doors opening; beds unmade; candles extinguished; icons falling; fire hallucinations; chairs floating; stopped clocks moving-Tanagras cautiously examined the Mavrovo case.
At first small items disappeared and reappeared-pins, rags-in the garden. Suspecting witchcraft led to quarrels with neighbors.

Then damage escalated: windows, glassware shattered; clothes, ties, coats, mattresses, berets-all torn the same way, starting with a triangle then ripping completely. Only one glass survived. Food stores were ruined: cheese barrels toppled; fuel and milk spilled; flour thrown and soaked; pantry goods scattered. The family fled because they could neither eat nor cook-pots were hurled.

At first locals mocked and came to see the 'haunted house.' For six months the phenomena were mild; then for 13 consecutive days they intensified. Eyewitness Dr. Stanos, excluding the maid, saw flour flung, furniture overturned. Former MP Tsantilis and student Papalabrou also witnessed events.

Once, while only 7-year-old Panagiota was home, she suddenly saw things flying everywhere. Another time a large table descended from the upper to lower floor. Another: the owner saw a stone break a window that could not have been thrown from outside. A big round table rolled while pans moved; tables and chairs 'danced.'
What explains it

Tanagras attributed it to telekinesis and hypnosis-phenomena science accepts, like wireless transmission of a signal. The key is the body's dynamism: a force acting contrary to mechanical laws. The cause is always someone in the house-the 'dynamogenic' factor-always involuntary, like radium emitting radiation.
He then recounted his actions in Kastoria and Kozani to found a GSPR center and his visit to the medium, Kalliopi, a 35-year-old married in a Grevena village.

She was thin with wild eyes. At 15 she had meningitis; afterwards she sweated heavily and had stomach pains-important medically, said Tanagras. She saw furniture dance; when she looked at an object, it fell. She despised the Turks who had tried to Islamize her.

She felt as much weight as the object moving. Wherever she went, things overturned. Tables spun; objects passed through barred windows-if glass was present, they did not pass. Sometimes plates flew and didn't break; in others' presence, they did. In Mrs. Chalkia's home, sacks of wheat rolled to the storage by themselves after the servant quipped, 'Let Kalliopi do the work.'
A squirrel skin stuffed with straw bounced around; plates and forks floated. Once an icon followed her outside while floating, though tied down.

These phenomena faded gradually after Kalliopi married. Early on, her dowry was found hung on nails and her mother-in-law fumed; Kalliopi claimed she put them there to avoid moths. Her first husband emigrated to America. Seven years later she married a shepherd in Miloneti; he left her too, with two children.

Tanagras hypnotized her and convinced her to come to Athens. Locals agreed to support her two children. She was admitted to Kozani hospital to reproduce phenomena under scientific conditions with the doctors there.
Conclusion

Tanagras concluded that if her old memories return, Greece will gain a medium of immense value that will honor Greek science. He stressed the need to found an institute, as France did via Jean Meyer's donation, because this science will lead us to the purpose of life. We now see the phenomena but not the cause; we will learn our true nature.
We will realize we are temporary residents of this fleeting planet, destined to fly to other blue expanses when we rest. As for life's pains-let us hope...

articles.title: Telekinetic Activity 1925 - Crete
articles.excerpt: Two dream warnings foretold a grandfather's death in Neapoli, Crete-an example of symbolic and vivid telepathic impressions.

content.value: Professor Spyridon K. Georgiou, appointed in 1925 to the Neapoli Gymnasium of Crete, was living there with his mother when one Friday morning she awoke deeply upset by a dream.
She had seen many deceased relatives, dressed for a celebration, going to her father's house-50 km away-for some official occasion.
She interpreted the dream as certain proof of her father's death. Georgiou tried to reassure her, stressing they would have been notified if something bad had happened.
The next night a second dream increased her agitation and certainty: she saw her father all dressed up, taking her hand, kissing her, and saying, 'I'm leaving, my child...'
This time nothing could calm her: 'Say what you like...I am sure father is dead.'
Georgiou, himself influenced by the dreams, withdrew to his room and noted the dates.

Three days later a letter from his uncle announced the grandfather's death on Saturday night-the night of the second dream-and added that the dying man kept asking for his daughter whom he loved dearly.
Here we have two telepathic experiences corresponding to the two dreams: the first symbolic, the second representational.
In the first, Mrs. Georgiou's Subconscious (or soul) sensed telepathically-perhaps from the physicians attending the dying man-his hopeless condition and imminent end.
The impression could also have come from the old man's own anxious thoughts. Her brain symbolized the impression as a dream of dead relatives coming to receive the soon-to-die.
There is a widespread belief that deceased relatives appear at the moment of death to welcome their own.

articles.title: Long Distance Psychic Phenomena
articles.excerpt: Examples of dramatic telepathic impressions at the moment of death-from a dying mother's message to a guitar's sudden vibration-and what they imply about the soul.

content.value: The vision is representational telepathy with an auditory illusion, because those words were not actually spoken. Telepathy gave Mr. Rouben the impression of hearing the dying woman's thought.

It is also possible that the telepathic impression of death automatically triggered Mr. Rouben's own thoughts about protecting his sisters-thoughts he already had after the doctor warned of his mother's desperate condition.

Another case: Shortly before the death of Nikolaos Koutsogiannis, director of the legal department of the National Bank, his doctor Georgios Moschidis escorted the dying man's sister, Mrs. Maria Moschou, home so she would not be present at the death.
As they sat on a sofa waiting for coffee, suddenly-before fifteen minutes had passed-they heard a guitar hanging on the wall opposite, about two meters high, vibrate loudly.
It was a strong 'grrring' as if all the strings had quivered at once. Frightened, they looked at each other and said the dying man must have just passed; they immediately checked the time.
Indeed, at that exact moment the patient expired. He loved to play the guitar, often accompanied in song by Mr. Moschidis, his close friend.
This episode and another described in the previous issue of Astynomika Chronika (at Prof. Varth. Gyzi's home) are characteristic examples of this striking form of deathbed telepathy.

Two explanations are possible. First: the dying man, through his beloved instrument, wanted to signal his sister and friend. This is the simplest, most seemingly logical, and most satisfying to human mysticism.

Second: one of the two mourners-perhaps Mrs. Moschou, who has strong intuition-was the unconscious cause. She subconsciously sensed her brother's death, but her Subconscious, for unknown reasons, could not send the impression to the brain in one of the usual forms (vision, image, psychopathic reaction, etc.).

Faced with that difficulty, it emitted a dynamolytic wave-a kind of psychic discharge-that vibrated the guitar strings symbolically so they would understand the calamity. Folk experience, which never errs in such cases, treats such manifestations as indisputable signs.
This dynamolytic wave-a sort of human 'radioactivity'-does not act like a blind force (a lightning bolt overturning an object) but like a rational will with a specific aim.

Thus, despite materialist dogmas, in critical moments certain people's bodies emit an unknown dynamic factor invisible to the senses which, though lacking flesh, muscle, bone, or brain, acts as if it possessed them.
In other words, we reach confirmation of the term Soul.

Because telekinetic phenomena can be proven experimentally, humanity today stands before an experimental proof of one of life's greatest problems-the soul-that philosophy tried to solve for thousands of years.

If this second explanation does not satisfy humanity's longing to communicate with beloved dead, it at least proves another great hope humanity has always intuited: that not everything about us is mere matter and blind mechanics; we are not just products of blind laws and chance.
Something spiritual, immaterial, immortal, and incorruptible exists within us which-in certain moments-can act consciously outside the body, wielding superhuman powers.

articles.title: Telepathy Between Birds and Dogs - Psychophysiological Study
articles.excerpt: A nightingale's farewell song appears in its owner's dream the night it dies-an example of telepathy or clairvoyant sensing between humans and animals.

content.value: The 1925 volume of Psychikai Ereynai published a strange telepathy episode about birds that could also be clairvoyance.

Maria Velissariou had a nightingale from Syria, where these birds are bred. She loved it so much she tended it herself, but when she fell gravely ill with typhoid others cared for it, which left her anxious.
During her recovery she dreamed one night that the nightingale flew to her shoulder and sang sweeter than ever, enchanting her.
In the morning she told her husband, who laughed that she saw her beloved bird even in sleep.
Soon after, to their surprise, the cook announced the nightingale was found dead in its cage.
Perhaps her Subconscious-freed during sleep and weakened by typhoid-sensed the bird's death and symbolized it as a farewell song.
With that explanation there is no need for telepathy between bird and sleeper.
Yet telepathy episodes between humans and animals are so convincing that the phenomenon can be considered indisputable.

articles.title: The Telepathy Case of Vissos Skalaios and His Dog
articles.excerpt: Editor Vissos Skalaios dreamt his dog Beka was dying at 6:30 a.m.; at that exact time she died from poison-an instance of human-animal telepathy.

content.value: In a previous issue we cited two cases from Vissos Skalaios, former director of the newspaper Eleftheros Anthropos. Here is a third, in his own words.
'On 14 September 1926, while sleeping, I dreamt around 6:30 a.m. that my beloved dog Beka in Chalandri had been poisoned and, with characteristic spasms, was dragging herself trying to reach me.
I half woke, then slept for another hour and a half when my brother-in-law Satras arrived from Chalandri and said: 'They stole the dog-people in a car took her.'
'She was poisoned,' I replied with strange certainty, recalling the dream. 'How do you know?' he asked, surprised, knowing I had been asleep.

He told me Beka had been poisoned by bait that morning and died precisely at 6:30. In her agony they called my name-'Beka! Beka, Vissos...'-and the loyal animal rose, made a last effort to crawl as I had seen in my dream, then fell dead.'

This touching episode shows how devoted animals can be. Telepathy cannot be ruled out: Skalaios likely received in sleep the telepathic impression of his dog's death and final movements from relatives who were present.

As it neared the islet of Vido in front of the harbor, it sank within minutes, bow first. He then met two crewmen who told him:
'We saw the ship taking water from a hole and used all our strength to reach the port. We couldn't-and only we two survived.'
In the morning he told his wife. Later he read in the papers a telegram from Corfu: a large Italian steamer with cement cargo sank near the Othonoi islet by Corfu; only two men survived.
This is a telepathy case: the sleeping Tzavellas-his Subconscious dominant-received the news from someone who had read the paper early or otherwise knew, acting as an unconscious sender.
The only difference is the islet's name (Vido vs Othonoi), insignificant since both belong to the Corfu group.

content.value: Notis Makris, painter and professor of drawing, had a little dog he adored, which always greeted him joyfully when he came home.
One noon, returning, the dog greeted him as usual. He spoke to it and played with it.
His astonishment was great when shortly after his sister told him the dog had been found dead earlier in the basement.
The impression was so vivid that he had to go see the body himself to be convinced.
Three explanations are possible: his family, thinking how the death would affect him, unconsciously transmitted that impression which his brain rendered as a hallucination of the animal's presence.
Or Makris sensed the death (clairvoyance) and his brain, influenced by the Subconscious, created the hallucination of the usual greeting scenes.
A third explanation is ectoplasm, which will be described later in Astynomika Chronika.

articles.title: Telepathy Case of Christovasilis and His Horse
articles.excerpt: Christovasilis' mare refused to continue and likely saved him from brigands; later he saw a black cross just as he learned his son had died-symbolic telepathy in both episodes.

content.value: Continuing human-animal telepathy cases: the father of writer Christovasilis, a tax farmer in Asia Minor, set out on horseback for a village.
Midway the mare refused to move. Spurs were useless; she reared but would not take a step.
Forced to return, he told locals, who approved: 'The horse knew something. Something bad would have happened to you.'
Indeed the next day a caravan coming the other way was attacked by bandits who killed and wounded many and looted the goods.

This, like Sarandidis' case in Asia Minor, shows telepathy between human and animal. The mare sensed the impending ambush; unable to transmit it clearly, her Subconscious produced terror and refusal to proceed.
Another time on Clean Monday, Christovasilis went to his office and was startled by a persistent vision of a black cross on the opposite wall.

The next day a Turkish friend warned him to leave for safety. The first part of the dream was pure telepathy: his wife received the decision of the would-be attackers. His survival can be explained by their intent merely to intimidate, the lucky deflection on the pin, or possibly telepathic suggestion causing the assassin's hand to veer.

articles.title: Telepathy and Illusion - Case Studies
articles.excerpt: Dr. Levidis' double deathbed vision and other 1920s telepathy cases-representational, symbolic, and apparitional impressions of deaths and injuries.

content.value: Case of Dr. Levidis, who interpreted a supposed ghost as telepathy.
One May night in 1928 he fell asleep around 1:30 a.m., woke about an hour later, and saw a 3-4-year-old girl in a nightgown passing his bed, visible only to the waist.

The vision was so vivid he asked, 'What do you want here, little one?' - 'I have died,' she said simply. 'I'm from the next house...' and vanished. Immediately a black-clad youth of 25 appeared: 'I just died too, but you don't know me!' He vanished.
Levidis, astonished, turned on the light-leaving it on to prove he was not dreaming-and checked the time: 1:45 a.m. (his clock a few minutes slow).
In the morning at breakfast he told his wife. Suddenly they saw mourning drapes at the neighboring door: the monomaniac child of neighbor Grigorios Korialos had died-a child Levidis had never seen.

Relative Capt. Spyr. Ferentinos confirmed to the GSPR that death occurred at exactly 1:50 a.m. Ferentinos also noted that at the cemetery he heard a father wailing over another coffin-that of a 25-year-old man.
Tanagras presented the case to the GSPR on April 4, 1928; Ferentinos attended and later came to the office to add observations.

For non-specialists, it looks like spirits appeared to announce their deaths. More likely it was simple telepathy during Levidis' hypnagogic state; he received two psychic 'signals' from the locations of the two deaths-probably from bystanders, not the dead themselves.
The brain, excited by the impression, symbolized the drama via visual hallucinations of the deceased. Logic also excludes that the dead would choose a stranger over their loved ones to appear to.

These small telepathy episodes matter: they show the many forms thought-transmission can take and help interpret more complex cases where imagination adds the dead.

articles.author: Angelos Tanagras

content.value: Angelos Tanagras, asked to give his view on the Vythos events, sent this letter.
He states the phenomena have nothing to do with vampires, dead spirits, or satanic forces. Modern research has experimentally clarified this issue.
In some homes, intense emotional shocks-deaths, accidents, painful illnesses-trigger strange occurrences that frighten families and sometimes mobilize police without result.

After a death, people assume the spirit of the deceased is acting. Yet the phenomena are trivial-moving objects, overturned furniture, knocks, or stone-throwing-too easy to fake. If the dead caused them, wouldn't they manifest in something weightier than, say, boxes of Turkish delight and glasses of water sliding from a cafe counter to tables? That would make one despair of any afterlife's intelligence.
Experimentally it is proven these events have a completely different cause: they are produced unconsciously by the living residents who have suffered strong psychic shock.
Just as inanimate isotopes become radioactive briefly, humans under intense shock can emit a kind of psychic radioactivity causing the 'haunted house' phenomena worldwide.
Curiously this psychoradiant emission acts consciously with superhuman properties, even moving objects. This proves the existence of soul within the living body.

Similar misunderstood events in 19th-century America were taken as proof of spirit communication and launched spiritualism. In my volumes of 'Psychikai Ereynai' (1925-1932) I published many such Greek cases from the GSPR's 29-year work-ignored by Greek institutions though psychophysiology is taught in foreign universities.
In Vythos, surely one of the four women in the house-mother or daughters-after the grandmother's death, was the unconscious cause; the kindly grandmother resting in the cemetery is innocent.
The reporter noticed the girls' abnormal nervousness and that the mother, at 45, is in menopause-a state that heightens nervous instability, easily exacerbated by shock.

Remedy for such turmoil and superstition: find the psychokinetic family member and remove them. I always advised police and local doctors to remove family members one by one to nearby villages until, upon one person's removal, the phenomena cease.
Fortunately psychokinetic outbreaks do not last; they stop once the nervous system calms and shock eases.
I trust police officers who attended my lectures will provide a reassuring scientific explanation.
Angelos Tanagras

articles.title: The Rouf Phenomena - 1929
articles.excerpt: Mysterious psychic incidents in the Rouf district caused panic; Angelos Tanagras explained them as hysteria, suggestion, and mass mimicry.

content.value: How to explain the strange phenomena that upset Rouf

Rumors about mysterious events-young Christos Christodoulou and Maritsa Papadimitriou suffered hysterical muteness; both recovered yesterday. They refused photos but allowed sketches. Is there a hidden romance?
In the Rouf neighborhood odd psychic episodes appeared involving the youth Christos Christodoulou and Maritsa Papadimitriou. The area remains agitated.
Yesterday further stories spread: other boys and girls supposedly had epileptic fits, became aphasic, spoke to invisible forces-sometimes screaming, sometimes fainting.
One tale concerned a homeless boy living on alms; he allegedly dreamed the Virgin's icon was buried in a nearby alley. Pious locals dug in various spots, of course finding nothing.
What happened to our photographer

When our reporters first arrived to verify the reports and photograph the boy and girl, a curious event occurred. The youths refused to be photographed, claiming the Virgin had forbidden Christos to pose.

They reacted violently at the sight of the camera, forcing the photographer to leave. Yet even far outside the house, when he tried to photograph the exterior-doors and windows shut-Christodoulou inside began shouting the moment the shutter clicked.
Yesterday, however, Christos was cheerful, the crisis past, and agreed to be sketched-insisting it look good. Maritsa, also better, wanted a sketch but her parents refused.
The youths the next day

Since the previous evening the two had weathered the storm that shook the neighborhood. Calm and good-humored, they explained to curious visitors what they had seen and felt. They remembered everything in detail.
Maritsa remains quiet and lets Christos speak for both. The handsome teenager repeats the now-familiar story to anyone who asks.
Our reporters found him reading a newspaper and confirming what had been written. He recalls what he said, how his family acted, and what everyone did during his seizure-with remarkable precision.
He insists he did not wish to kill himself when thrashing about-only to gouge out his eyes. He felt a force compelling it and could not resist, though he knew it meant his ruin.
He bears scratches around his right eye and other marks on his face confirming his account. Christos swears he saw the Virgin and banged his head on the wall without knowing why.
What Tanagras says
For a scientific explanation we visited Angelos Tanagras. At the request of the city police he examined both youths at their home and brought them to the GSPR offices.
Tanagras ruled it a typical case of hysterical muteness with no mystery; the girl's symptoms were autosuggestion from the shock of seeing Christos-whom she seems closely linked to.
He noted a prior romance may have enabled the contagion by suggestion. Such a condition could spread to more people and should surprise no one.
Chorea and mimicry

Many people, through autosuggestion, may lose speech or develop the nervous state called chorea-violent jerks of limbs and head from nerve irritation. It can spread to several people; the infant-like movements gave it the name chorea.
Transmission by suggestion-even without the recipient's will-rests on a broad natural law: mimicry. Matter, living or not, tends to repeat phenomena or automatically imitate what happens nearby.
Regarding Christodoulou's claim he saw the Virgin, Tanagras said he likely did: steeped in religious tradition, his mind accepted the possibility of visions of saints and imagined figures.
Tanagras also praised the city police for calling the GSPR to examine the case scientifically and provide the real explanation.

'Mr. Tanagras, for God's sake, pity us-stones are raining!'

The entire district knew he was coming. When his car reached the Piraeus-Tambouria border, hundreds awaited, held back by heavy police. Streets leading to the mysterious house at 134 Goura were packed. A second police cordon surrounded M. Apostolopoulos' home. His arrival brought sighs of relief: at last the two-month mystery might be solved.
Tanagras was briefed by Miss Galateia Chamodraka, head of the Piraeus electric branch and herself keen on psychophysiology.
The phenomena began two months prior. One evening Mrs. Apostolopoulou was hit by a stone in her yard. Since then, stones fell nightly-and not only stones, but anything imaginable.

Victim Othon Raftopoulos presented the latest 'production': a basket full of objects-stones, screws, pocketknives, pencils, tiles, broken plates, even a box of matches with a tube of hair pomade folded inside, as if the spirit groomed itself.
'Very suspicious,' Tanagras said laughing. Chamodraka marveled: 'Strange-other nights at 9:30 stones fell in torrents.'
Before she finished, a frightened youth reported: 'Just now while speaking with the policeman, I was hit by a stone-it seemed to fall straight down.'
'Was it warm?' asked Tanagras. 'No, cold.' 'Then it isn't a phenomenon,' he replied. In telekinesis, falling stones are usually warm.
Dimes, drachmas, francs
'Shall we go to the yard?' suggested Chamodraka. 'Perhaps the phenomena will start.'
She was right: no sooner had we sat in the yard than objects began falling from the grape arbor. A colleague cried, 'Something hit me!'-a metallic sound followed. We looked: a 20-lepta coin.
Coins kept coming-dimes, 20-lepta, 5-lepta, drachmas-mysteriously from the arbor. We gathered them; the take totaled 16.80 drachmas and three packs of cigarettes.
'Are these truly telekinesis?' someone asked. 'Perhaps-if they were sterling,' Tanagras joked.
The phenomena would not stop. A lady was hit by a stone; she cried, 'Hot! Hot!' Tanagras touched it: 'Cold,' he said. The mystery remained; the few coins and stone meant nothing.
Hunting the medium
'Let's find the medium,' said Tanagras. Inside the Apostolopoulos parlor he began testing with a compass, asking each person to hold out their hands and try to move the needle-nothing.
All were tested except one little girl about 14, in puberty-Ritsa Raftopoulou. 'Perhaps the little one is the medium,' said Tanagras. 'In puberty both boys and girls can produce telekinesis.'
Her test made the compass quiver faintly. 'We must continue,' he said. The examination moved privately: Tanagras, little Ritsa, and her brother Othon withdrew. Minutes felt like ages.
The door burst open; the frightened girl emerged. 'What is it, Ritsa?' 'I'm scared! They covered my eyes, told me to sleep. When I began to drift I panicked.'
Tanagras followed. 'Was she the one?' 'Perhaps-the little girl is nervous, which contributes. But mysteries aren't solved at once.'
He instructed the family: remove the girl from the house for a few days; if she is the medium, the phenomena will stop.
Our mission ended there-not so for police. By yesterday fifteen pranksters had been arrested and convicted; they had taken advantage of the uproar to pelt the house with stones.
As we parted, Tanagras said, 'If the little one could be hypnotized, the mystery would have been solved tonight. But mysteries rarely yield easily.'

articles.title: The Light of Alexander the Great in Macedonia - Explanations by the GSPR President
articles.author: Mich. Rodas
articles.excerpt: Luminous phenomena near Igoumenitsa were ascribed by villagers to Alexander the Great's spirit; Angelos Tanagras offers a natural explanation and dispels the myth.

image.alt: Luminous phenomena and the myth of Alexander the Great

content.value: A short trip to Macedonia let me learn about the 'light of Alexander the Great' that appears and hovers nightly near a village of Igoumenitsa.
Villagers saw nearby flashes that grew and rotated in curious patterns; most were terrified, thinking of ghosts.
Others, bolder, watched and alerted authorities. The Thessaloniki paper Makedonia sent a reporter who confirmed and described the lights as they appeared and faded.
That the lights were said to come from Alexander's spirit was mere inspiration and historical fancy-antiquities lie nearby and people believe the great commander passed there.
The matter ended with a request for GSPR president Angelos Tanagras' opinion; Makedonia invited him to investigate on site.
He replied it was difficult to leave Athens then and suggested the physics professor of Giannitsa Gymnasium observe and report.
Tanagras suspects the cause is animal skeletons in local marshes emitting phosphorescence, as often happens in cemeteries.
As for the Alexander myth, it remains a myth beloved by popular imagination. Fortunately the GSPR exists to dispel such legends or provide serious scientific explanations.

articles.title: Telekinetic Phenomena at Kalamaki - 1937
articles.author: Akropolis
articles.excerpt: Clothing slashed and objects disturbed in merchant Drakopoulos' Kalamaki home in 1937, traced to the unconscious telekinesis of his 16-year-old servant.

image.alt: Telekinetic phenomena in a Kalamaki home (1937)

content.value: New telekinetic phenomena came to light in recent days at Kalamaki, in the home of Stadiou-street merchant Mr. Drakopoulos.
The incidents resemble those two years earlier at General Diamantopoulos' house: attributed there, as here, to the young maid.
From the first day, garments and household linens were damaged without cause.
At first the family blamed the maid's carelessness; when damage continued despite precautions, they grew worried.
Damage centered on fabrics appearing neatly snipped.
The holes had precise shapes, as if cut deliberately with scissors-proof of conscious action, just like in the Diamantopoulos case.
Due to the servant
The Drakopoulos family alerted Kalamaki police and also contacted the GSPR.
GSPR president Angelos Tanagras visited the house and solved the mystery.
He judged it routine telekinesis caused unconsciously by the 16-year-old maid, Anna Apergi, employed there for months.
At his suggestion, the maid was removed from the house; the phenomena will cease and peace return.
What Tanagras says
Tanagras told our reporter: 'The phenomena undoubtedly stem from the young maid in adolescence.
Some people, under puberty or other bodily upheavals, become dynamolytic like radioactive bodies.
Instead of manifesting as illness or hysterical fit, the energy discharges as dynamolysis-the cause of so-called haunted houses.
The phenomena always follow one household member; remove that person and they stop-or start anew elsewhere.
They also mirror the hidden feelings of the dynamolytic person-resentment, psychic tension-hence damage to clothes, furniture, objects.
So it was at General Diamantopoulos' home, with damage around 25,000 drachmas.
In the Drakopoulos case the pattern was clearer: his own things stayed intact while his wife's dresses and household linens suffered.
Tanagras also mentioned cases of 'psychobolia' (evil eye), explaining they share the same radiative cause as telekinesis.

articles.title: Angelos Goulandris - The Athenian Youth Who Speaks with the Dead - 1936
articles.author: Apogevmatini
articles.excerpt: In Gargaretta, 16-year-old Angelos Goulandris claims nightly dictation from a luminous historical figure amid crashes and object movements, drawing crowds and medical scrutiny.

image.alt: Angelos Goulandris talks with the dead (1936)

content.value: In a small house on Ioannou Moreos street near Veikou stop, events have upset the Gargaretta district.
The Constantinople-born Goulandris family lives there-father, mother, two sons. The elder, 16-year-old Angelos, studied at Leonteios until last winter when a mysterious condition struck.

Two or three nights a week between 11 and midnight he feels an historical figure incarnate within him, forcing him to lock himself in a room where he receives written orders from the luminous person seated before him.
In nervous excitement, he hears the materialized spirit and writes its instructions, filling pages. This continues to this day.
His worried parents kept it secret and called university lecturer Dr. Petzetakis to examine him.

Meanwhile the neighborhood learned from the loud crashes accompanying each arrival and departure of the spirit; neighbors concluded the house was haunted and gather outside at the appointed hour to hear the bangs.
What Dr. Petzetakis says
The lecturer who examined Angelos explained:

'I was indeed called to examine him. He is healthy and mentally sound when calm. But at certain moments he shows neurophysiological disturbance: sudden muscle spasms-especially in the arm-then, as if driven by irresistible force, he rushes into a room, sits at a table.
The event comes with demonic crashes and movements of objects felt throughout the house.

The youth says light issues from his head, becoming the historical figure. Then the crashes cease and a conversation begins between him and the figure, audible to others-a deep voice softer than his. When it ends, the crashes resume; the youth emerges and recounts everything.
Examination immediately afterward-conversation lasts 90 minutes-finds him mentally normal, as if nothing happened.
Physically he shows severe tachycardia for half an hour afterward.
We proposed a microphone in the room and photographing the luminous arc that precedes the figure, but the family refused.

In my view these are ordinary telekinetic phenomena. Scientifically interesting is the second voice: we must learn if it is unconscious ventriloquism during ecstasy, or ectoplasmic voice-verification would be valuable.'
Explanation of the phenomena
Asked how to explain the Gargaretta events, Petzetakis said:
'The phenomena caused by Angelos Goulandris are typical telekinesis appearing especially in adolescence in hysterical personalities. They may stop abruptly or persist in various forms.

They appear here as visions, telekinesis, automatism, and ectoplasmic action. The ectoplasmic force develops at a moment of ecstasy and acts outside the body without the person's will. Science cannot yet explain ectoplasmic force.
I am collaborating with GSPR president Tanagras, who also deems them ordinary telekinetic phenomena seen in some adolescents.'
And the crowd
Petzetakis gave the history, used terminology, and after explaining ectoplasmic power, admitted science offers no final answer.
So the history and terms clarified nothing. We left uninformed. Only the house, the crashes, the phenomena remained.

Arriving at Veikou we needed no directions: dense crowds ringed the house. Families returning home, workers, girls, housewives with slippers, robes, and babies; maids; neighbors; swarms of children five to fifteen.
A lone policeman, cool observer, told our reporter confidently: 'It's nothing-a television!' and walked on.
The people were talkative and critical. Most had heard the crashes; others heard whistles or saw flashes; everyone heard or saw something.

'What does the boy see?' we asked. 'Don't you know? He sees some politician dictating pages three times a week, ordering him to read them years later when of age,' replied one woman. The baker across added, 'Tomorrow he will come not alone but with another.'

Such were the debates-skepticism, credulity, arguments, jibes. All fancied themselves experts, yet no one grew wiser from the polyphonic popular commentary. Only by observing could one hope to interpret.
Apogevmatini, 12.09.1936, p.1
